snippet.textDisplay: I awoke from a dream this morning, that our universe is a self-contained universe within an extremely large universe, where nothing inside can affect the outside, actual universe. What is inside our bubble has no consequence upon the real universe, because this is our playground, and if we, or others inside it go in the wrong direction, it will not affect the larger reality. Our universe can be destroyed or created in a moment, by us or others, and is a safe zone for gaining maturity. Everything cycles in and among itself within our universe, yet creates the illusion of expansion, yet there are defined borders, as a snow globe would behave. In this dream, no one can leave this universe until a set level of conscious maturity is reached, until then, it is our playing field to find out who we are, and get through our dangerous tendencies. ( Just thought I would share this, because it does seem relevant. The idea is that this creation of our universe has been done many times before.)

snippet.textDisplay: While I am no Physicist or Scientist by any means and Math is not my strong suit you touched on something I have thought about for some time. A White hole as the big bang.  I know you said as a fact that it cant be but what if it is. Think of it this way We are riding on a bubble or a balloon that is constantly expanding due to pressure from the inside. While we ride that balloon its surface expands as more pressure continues to push from the inside. Now inside our bubble is another bubble or wave of stuff that has been expelled from the big bang radiating outward another dimension and under that is another and another. The big bang is still going on we just cant see it and there might even be another universe above us heading for the big rip when the bubble bursts. While I got no math to back it up and no degree in science I would like to think that the idea has some merit. I mean it does give reason to dark matter, dark energy and the multiverse theory all rolled up into one and proves Einstein correct that a White hole could exist.
snippet.textOriginal: While I am no Physicist or Scientist by any means and Math is not my strong suit you touched on something I have thought about for some time. A White hole as the big bang. snippet.textDisplay:
Scientifically and biblically the Earth AND the Universe is 6000 years old. The reason is that every halftime formula has a proposjonal factor c inside the formula. C is now relatively constant since 1980. Before that it was exponentially higher and more than a billion times faster at the time of creation. Billions of atomic years went by in record time.
The biggest mistake in astronomic history is to multiply c with z (redshift) and make it a distanse in lightyears and thereby years. That would have been true if c always have been a constant. C is not a constant, but hc is a constant because they are inversely proportional.
snippet.textOriginal:
Scientifically and biblically the Earth AND the Universe is 6000 years old. The reason is that every halftime formula has a proposjonal factor c inside the formula. C is now relatively constant since 1980. Before that it was exponentially higher and more than a billion times faster at the time of creation. Billions of atomic years went by in record time.
The biggest mistake in astronomic history is to multiply c with z (redshift) and make it a distanse in lightyears and thereby years. That would have been true if c always have been a constant. C is not a constant, but hc is a constant because they are inversely proportional.

snippet.textDisplay: The problem with basing the calculation of the age of geological material on radioactive decay is that it is inaccurate. This is mainly due to the erroneous premise that radioactive decay is constant. It is not. Radioactive decay fluctuates wildly. It changes due to material being covered by water (ice ages, flood) for at least a year and it changes according to the distance between the earth, moon and the sun. The earth and moon revolves around the sun in the elliptical each year and so the radioactive decay of materials on earth varies gradually every year. Dating on the premise of a constant and steady radioactive decay is only accurate to about 4,000 old specimens. Yet,  modern methods are the best scientist can do or have done yet.
snippet.textOriginal: The problem with basing the calculation of the age of geological material on radioactive decay is that it is inaccurate. This is mainly due to the erroneous premise that radioactive decay is constant. It is not. Radioactive decay fluctuates wildly. It changes due to material being covered by water (ice ages, flood) for at least a year and it changes according to the distance between the earth, moon and the sun. The earth and moon revolves around the sun in the elliptical each year and so the radioactive decay of materials on earth varies gradually every year. Dating on the premise of a constant and steady radioactive decay is only accurate to about 4,000 old specimens. Yet,  modern methods are the best scientist can do or have done yet.

snippet.textDisplay:
"We can trace the process of evolution, by matching the fossil record to the geologic clock."
No you can't, unless you're accepting certain "ASSUMPTIONS" as "FACTS."
"We've found fossils as old as 3.5 billion years."
No you haven't; you base your fossil "dates" on the ASSUMED date of the layers those fossils are found in, and you date the layers by the ASSUMED age of the fossils found in them. That's NOT science, that's called "circular reasoning."
Finally, your radiometric dating claim suffer from the same dilemma: yet again, you merely ASSUME the elemental "rate of decay" has always been constant. Yet sites such as Oklo in Africa provide evidence to the contrary, with its Samarium decay rate paradox. You ASSUME that elemental half-lives (for Carbon, Samarium, Uranium, Lead, etc.) have ALWAYS been the same, but you DON'T actually know that. Then there is other contradictory evidence like Polonium halos, the fact that the atmosphere has NOT reach C14 saturation, meaning you CAN'T use it as a baseline to carbon date things, the possibility of the rate of inflation after the "BB" accounting for the current size of the universe, the horizon problem, upheavals caused by catastrophes, etc.
Bottom Line: IF your ASSUMPTIONS are correct, then you MAY be right, however, you've no way of knowing they are.
That's WHY you actually DON'T know that "the Earth is ancient."
You just BELIEVE it is. You arguments are good, but only as good as your assumptions.
snippet.textOriginal:
"We can trace the process of evolution, by matching the fossil record to the geologic clock."
No you can't, unless you're accepting certain "ASSUMPTIONS" as "FACTS."
"We've found fossils as old as 3.5 billion years."
No you haven't; you base your fossil "dates" on the ASSUMED date of the layers those fossils are found in, and you date the layers by the ASSUMED age of the fossils found in them. That's NOT science, that's called "circular reasoning."
Finally, your radiometric dating claim suffer from the same dilemma: yet again, you merely ASSUME the elemental "rate of decay" has always been constant. Yet sites such as Oklo in Africa provide evidence to the contrary, with its Samarium decay rate paradox. You ASSUME that elemental half-lives (for Carbon, Samarium, Uranium, Lead, etc.) have ALWAYS been the same, but you DON'T actually know that. Then there is other contradictory evidence like Polonium halos, the fact that the atmosphere has NOT reach C14 saturation, meaning you CAN'T use it as a baseline to carbon date things, the possibility of the rate of inflation after the "BB" accounting for the current size of the universe, the horizon problem, upheavals caused by catastrophes, etc. 
Bottom Line: IF your ASSUMPTIONS are correct, then you MAY be right, however, you've no way of knowing they are.
That's WHY you actually DON'T know that "the Earth is ancient."
You just BELIEVE it is. You arguments are good, but only as good as your assumptions.

snippet.textDisplay: the difference between white hole and the big bang seem to be based on perspective. Who is to say the big bang didnt expand into something, so far the universe as we know it, is the "observable universe".  At one point we thought our solar system was the universe, then we thought galaxy were the universe, so that definition has changed over time, mot to mention that universe shouldn't be confused with existance. to say space adn time was created at the big bang, seems to eb a far reaching statement, its just the space we see now in its current state, the aftermath a "big bang". When you set off a bomb, the surroundings from the epicenter weren't created at that time, it the furthest back in time you can trace that areas history to.  Of course if your a colony of ants that evolved. living on a hill who discovered science, you would think the same thing, because how else would you have evidence of what was there before, especially if all you can see s evidence of expansion from the epicenter. To say a white hole expands into something, and the big bang just expanded (cosmic expansion); that seems like semantics. im probably wrong, but it would make sense if black holes emptied into white holes in other parts of the universe, making a bunch of "bubble universe" that never interact. because the speed at which they expand and the time it takes for life to randomly evolve'; ensuring a complete reset of matter down to information ( getting smeared all over event horizon within the universe it originated in)

snippet.textDisplay:
As a recent grad with a BSc in Geology I love that this channel has taken on this issue. I have some questions that I am hoping someone can help me out with.


1) Has time dilation due to universal expansion been taken into consideration when calculating the age of the earth? When calculating decay constants? (Also is there a reason why this question may be invalid?)
2) A previous SpaceTime video mentioned that the fundamental constants may be changing. If over large timescales even this pillar of our understanding of Physics is subject to uncertainty how can we use the model of uniformitarianism to explain the age of the earth? ie: We have only been observing the way things work for a few centuries. We only understand things from our tiny sliver of geologic time which is not at all representative of the whole (imagine we were observing conditions right after the Chicxulub impact, or some other period with significantly different conditions than those found today).



I think a lot of the controversy over this topic comes down to the logical fallacy of an argument from Authority. Essentially the argument usually boils down to "Scientists say..." or "God says..." without actually going into the details of why each side believes what they do. The solution is to address the legitimate problems that surround each argument, instead descending into a futile argument about what is the greater authority, God or Science. For example: https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0026-1394/52/3/S51 this article outlines the issues with radiometric dating. Radiometric dating is often presented as a foolproof solution in order to persuade people that the earth is old. Realizing that it is not a fool proof solution, but it is the best we've got right now actually has more impact than pushing it as a foolproof solution.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Surly the Copernican Principle assumes the fact that we aren't the only intelligent life form that exists in the entire universe. Something we have absolutely no proof of, yet. I know it's supposed to say more about the fact that physics is the same everywhere and that we can take it for granted that, if other observers do exist then their physics will be the same as ours. Still as of now we can in some ways assume we're in a privileged position as the only observer's of the universe.

snippet.textDisplay: RCD relies on the assumption that nuclear decay rates are constant.  This assumption was empirically disproven by Brookhaven National Lab in 1986 by Alburger et al and later confirmed by M.A. Silver et al in 2010 which leads to the conclusion that the only way that RCD can be reliable is if the conditions controlling decay rates stays constant which is disproven by the experiments referenced.
snippet.textOriginal: RCD relies on the assumption that nuclear decay rates are constant.  This assumption was empirically disproven by Brookhaven National Lab in 1986 by Alburger et al and later confirmed by M.A. Silver et al in 2010 which leads to the conclusion that the only way that RCD can be reliable is if the conditions controlling decay rates stays constant which is disproven by the experiments referenced.

Does anyone know if there are any relevant episodes?
Perhaps in (non-deterministic) future episodes?

snippet.textDisplay: How accurate is uranium-lead radiometric dating? Like how many sig. figs. can we confidently claim? I grew up a “Bible Thumper” and my family still is. One question they’ve had is why carbon dating and other methods of radiometric dating are so different in their predictions for the age of the earth and the universe. I don’t know about this subject well enough to give them a proper answer. But more importantly, I’m curious and I want to know how the process works. It seems odd that radiometric decay is simultaneously accurate down to the nanosecond within the context of atomic clocks and also only accurate to within a few million years in the context of the age of the Earth.
snippet.textOriginal: How accurate is uranium-lead radiometric dating? Like how many sig. figs. can we confidently claim? I grew up a “Bible Thumper” and my family still is. One question they’ve had is why carbon dating and other methods of radiometric dating are so different in their predictions for the age of the earth and the universe. I don’t know about this subject well enough to give them a proper answer. But more importantly, I’m curious and I want to know how the process works. It seems odd that radiometric decay is simultaneously accurate down to the nanosecond within the context of atomic clocks and also only accurate to within a few million years in the context of the age of the Earth.

snippet.textDisplay: The Big Bang Theory does not predict an infinitely dense universe with zero size.  At size equals zero the formula has no solution, divide by zero is undefined. It has no physical meaning.  It is true that density approaches infinite and size approaches zero, but you must stop before zero.  When dividing by zero you do not get "Equals Infinite." You just have a broken theory at that point.  Some people might choose to interpret it as that, personally, but that is not the consensus of scientists.  We just don't know at this point.
snippet.textOriginal: The Big Bang Theory does not predict an infinitely dense universe with zero size.  At size equals zero the formula has no solution, divide by zero is undefined. It has no physical meaning.  It is true that density approaches infinite and size approaches zero, but you must stop before zero.  When dividing by zero you do not get "Equals Infinite." You just have a broken theory at that point.  Some people might choose to interpret it as that, personally, but that is not the consensus of scientists.  We just don't know at this point.

snippet.textDisplay:
Do people really believe this? Are “big words” so much more impressive than the fact that all of this is pure speculation and that it always has been? From the beginning this hasn’t been true science....but I guess to an audience of people that think this is making them “smart” it’s not too hard to fool a crowd. I wish more people would think for themselves. A bunch of Computer generated images (CGI), a guy with an accent, and a PBS insignia and you ignore your own eyes and common sense. What a cop out to doing some real research by thinking “I’m too dumb” you don’t have to be a “scientist” to realize this is fake. You just have to be willing to call a duck a duck. Have we become so conditioned as a society? I pray you all wake up.


https://youtu.be/7nFwPDZF_Z8
